title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.10.34-36 | 21-06-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: So the description is Krishna has started from Hastināpura and he is going to proceed towards Dvārakā crossing the different parts of the land in between Hastināpura and Dvārakā.
segments.summary: Suta Goswami describes Krishna's journey from Hastinapura to Dvārakā, mentioning the various provinces he passed through.

segments.key_quote: They are real happenings. Just because it does not fit with our logical thinking, we should not reject them as mythology or something unacceptable, unbelievable.
segments.summary: Srila Prabhupada emphasizes the historical accuracy of the Bhagavatam, refuting modern theories about the formation of deserts and the limitations of modern researchers.

segments.key_quote: Kurukshetra continues to exist since the Vedic age and it is sheer foolishness when interpreters ignore or deny the existence of Kurukshetra
segments.summary: The speaker refutes interpretations of Bhagavad-gita that deny the literal existence of Kurukshetra, emphasizing the importance of receiving knowledge through the parampara system.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is never under the laws of karma. Krishna is the master of all the laws of material nature.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that while Krishna appears to follow Vedic principles, he is not bound by karma, unlike ordinary beings who are subject to the laws of karma.

segments.key_quote: Krishna also teaches by his own example how to follow the Vedic injunctions... One must act properly himself and teach the others how to follow the Vedic injunctions by his own actions.
segments.summary: Krishna sets an example by following Vedic injunctions, but not all his actions are meant to be imitated; one must distinguish between what to follow and what not to imitate.

segments.key_quote: Therefore, one should be guided by the bona fide spiritual master. To distinguish between what we should follow among the activities of Krishna and which actions of Krishna are not to be imitated, the spiritual master should be the guide.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of the sun and Shiva to illustrate the dangers of imitating powerful figures, emphasizing the need for guidance from a bona fide spiritual master in bhakti practice.
